passage.title: An eye for detail
passage.content:
Artist Carmen Rodriguez, sixty-five, says: But the gradual decaying process is also part of the fascination for her. With tulips, for example, you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for perhaps a day and they each form themselves into different shapes. They open out and are fantastic. When you first put them in a vase, you think they are boring, but they change all the time with twists and turns.

Carmen has always been interested in plants. 'I did botany at school and used to collect wild flowers from all around the countryside.' In the garden, she wasn't much interested in gardening then; I thought they were artificial looking. I only really liked ones were wild.' Nowadays, the garden owes its beauty to imported plants that originated in far-off lands, though they seem as much at home in her garden as they did in China or the Himalayas. She has a come-what-may attitude to the garden, rather like an affectionate aunt who is quite happy for children to play about undisciplined as long as they don't do any serious damage.

With two forthcoming exhibitions to prepare for, and a ready supply of subject material at her back door, finding time to paint is never a problem for Carmen recently. She now employs an extra gardener, but admits she need to paint, she knows that to maintain her connection with her subject matter, you have to get your hands dirty.

Her busiest time of year is spring and early summer, when the tulips are out followed by the poppies. They all come out together, and you're so busy she says. 'I take one flower out and paint it which is how I like to work, and then bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish.'

Carmen prefers to focus on detailed studies of individual plants rather than on the garden as a whole, though she will occasionally paint a group of plants when positioned so as to provide the best viewing angle for the artist. She also inherited the gardener, Danny. In fact, 'I was really not interested in gardening.' We got on very well at first but would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it to some of the things I wanted to put in, but when I said I wanted to plant them, he recognized what I had in mind.'

Carmen prefers her grey suit. She liked the grey suit. She had liked it for a very long time, she said of a woman's advice that it was better to buy an expensive suit that would last than to keep buying cheap suits that looked very smart for a short while until they got dirty and out at the seat. The grey suit had been what she shop that called a 'classic,' which meant that nobody would ever turn round in the street to look at it, but it would stand having its skirt taken up or let down according to the swings of fashion.

Carmen was wearing her grey suit today. She liked the grey suit. She had liked it very early afternoon with the rain, she liked the way it was always glad to get away from it at lunchtime, even though it meant queuing for a table in one of the restaurants and tea-shops that fed the local shop-workers. Here people tended to eat with their eyes on the clock, often failing to taste what they ate and thinking only of getting their food down as early as possible. Carmen: once second, enjoyed a leisurely, if lonely, sandwich.

Some of the more advanced swimmers were able to dive down with these dolphins, an experience they clearly enjoyed.

In fact, they are very sociable animals, always supporting each other within the pod. The guides are beginning to recognize some of the local dolphins by the markings on their backs, and some individuals appear time after time.
A spotter plane circled above the bay, looking for large groups of dolphins close to the surface of the water.
These include mother gently guiding their young alongside; either to introduce them to the boat, or to proudly show off their babies. Yet, when they become bored with playing, they leave.
After 20 minutes, we sighted our first small pod. The dolphins came rushing towards the boat, swimming alongside and overtaking us until they could surf on the boat's bow wave.
Eventually it was time to leave, and the boat headed back to our starting point. We picked up another pod, which was joined by more and more dolphins until we had a large group.

However, touching the creatures is strongly discouraged. This is despite the fact that dolphins have a very friendly reputation, and have never been known to be aggressive towards human beings in the wild.
